['Avoidance - The action of keeping away or preventing something undesirable from occurring.', 'Deterrence - The act of discouraging someone from doing something through fear or doubt.', 'Prohibition - An official ban on a certain activity, substance, or behavior.', 'Prevention - The action of stopping something from happening or arising.', 'Inhibition - Restriction or suppression of an action or behavior.', 'Intervention - The act of becoming involved in order to alter the outcome of a situation.', 'Suppression - Forcibly putting an end to actions, feelings, or desires.', 'Mitigation - Reducing the severity or seriousness of something undesirable.', 'Foreclosure - The action of preventing someone from being able to do or have something due to legal proceedings.', 'Preclusion - The act of excluding, blocking or making impossible by prior agreement.', 'Disallowance - Permission not given; refusal to allow or approve.', 'Obstruction - Something that blocks progress, prevents action, or creates difficulties in achieving a goal.', 'Thwarting - To prevent something from happening or being achieved by overcoming it.', 'Curtailment - The act of reducing the extent, amount, or degree of something.', 'Nullification - Making null and void; rendering something legally ineffective.', 'Redirection - Changing the course or direction of something to prevent an undesirable outcome.', 'Deterrence (again) - The action of discouraging someone from doing something, as previously mentioned.', 'Inoculation - Protecting against infection by exposure to a small amount of a pathogen; metaphorically used for preventing negative influences or ideas.', 'Prevention (again) - The action of stopping something from happening or arising, as previously mentioned.', 'Hindrance - Something that causes delay, difficulty, or obstruction in doing something.']

['Detonate - to explode violently or suddenly.', 'Blow up - cause an object to explode or shatter.', 'Shatter - break something into small pieces with force.', 'Fragment - a piece broken off by explosion, erosion, etc.', 'Blast - a strong wind of gases and debris from an explosion.', 'Detonate - to cause or explode violently and suddenly.', 'Burst - break open suddenly with violence.', 'Pop - make a sudden loud noise due to something bursting, cracking, etc.', 'Explosion - rapid expansion resulting in an explosive sound or violent release of energy.', 'Smash - to forcefully hit and destroy something by breaking it into pieces.', 'Break apart - separate forcefully into smaller parts.', 'Dismantle - take something apart, piece by piece.', 'Collapse - fall down suddenly or give way under pressure or weight.', 'Disintegrate - break up into small parts; decay gradually to nothing.', 'Fragment - a smaller part broken off from the main object.', 'Shatter - smash violently against a surface, causing fragments to scatter.', 'Deflate - allow air or gas to escape rapidly from something, resulting in collapse.', 'Disperse - spread widely apart or over a wide area.', 'Snap - break suddenly and with a sharp cracking sound; shatter violently into pieces.', 'Rupture - tear or burst open suddenly and forcefully.']

['Croon - to sing or chant softly and gently, usually with a smooth voice.', 'Chant - rhythmically speaking or singing words in a religious or ceremonial context, often repetitively.', 'Carol - to sing festive songs during the holiday season.', 'Hymn - a song of praise, adoration, or prayer, typically sung in a church setting.', 'Lullaby - a soothing song played or sung to lull someone (usually an infant) to sleep.', 'Ode - a lyrical poem written in praise or celebration, often with musical qualities and accompanied by singing.', 'Ballad - a narrative poem that tells a story through verses, which can be sung.', 'Serenade - the act of performing a love song or piece for someone outside their home, usually at night.', 'Chorus - the repeated section in a song where the main melody and lyrics are sung by everyone.', "Anthem - an uplifting song that represents a group's identity, often sung during significant events such as sports games or political rallies.", 'Cantata - a vocal composition with instrumental accompaniment, typically having several movements and narrative elements.', 'Aria - a solo section in an opera, aria can be considered as the "singing" portion of the piece.', 'Duet - two singers performing together harmoniously or expressively to convey a musical storyline.', 'Minstrelsy - the performance by minstrels who sing and play music for entertainment, typically involving folk songs and traditional melodies.', 'Vocalize - to produce vocal sounds with various techniques such as singing, speaking, or humming.', 'Opera - an art form that combines singing and acting in a dramatic performance set to instrumental music, often accompanied by elaborate sets and costumes.', 'Reverberation - the prolonged reflection of sound waves in a closed space, creating a "singing" or echoing effect.', "Tune-up - to warm up one's vocal cords before singing with exercises such as humming or scales."]

['EEG (Electroencephalogram) - a recording of electrical activity along the scalp, often used to study different types of brainwaves.', 'Neuron - the basic unit of the nervous system and carrier of neural impulses.', 'Synapse - the junction or small gap between two neurons where transmission of nerve signals occurs.', "Axon - a long, slender projection of a nerve cell that conducts electrical impulses away from the neuron's cell body.", 'Dendrite - branch-like structures on a neuron which receive incoming messages from other cells.', 'Cerebrum - the largest part of the brain that is responsible for higher cognitive functions and processing sensory information, often associated with complex thought processes.', 'Hippocampus - an area in the brain associated with memory formation and retrieval.', 'Amygdala - a region within the temporal lobes involved in emotion regulation and fear response.', 'Cortical Activity - refers to the overall electrical activity that occurs on the surface of the cerebral cortex, which is linked to cognition and perception.', 'Brainwave Patterns - specific recurring patterns of brain waves associated with different states such as sleep, meditation or focused attention.', 'Neurotransmitter - a chemical substance released by neurons that allows them to communicate with other cells in the nervous system.', 'Cognitive Processing - complex thought processes involving perception, memory, decision-making and problem solving.', 'Slow Wave Activity (SWA) - refers to slow frequency brain waves during sleep, which is important for restoration and consolidation of memories.', 'Alpha Waves - a type of brain wave pattern often associated with relaxed wakefulness or meditation states.', 'Theta Waves - low-frequency brain activity commonly observed in light stages of sleep, early learning processes, and deep relaxation techniques.', 'Beta Waves - high frequency electrical patterns typically associated with active thinking, focus, and concentration.', 'Gamma Waves - the fastest and most synchronized brainwaves often linked to heightened perception, information processing, and cognitive functioning.', 'Neuroplasticity - refers to the ability of the brain to change in response to experience or injury by forming new neural connections or pathways.', 'Brainwave Entrainment - a technique that uses external stimuli (e.g., sound, light) to synchronize brainwaves with specific rhythms for therapeutic effects.', 'Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) - a neuroimaging technique used to measure and map brain activity by detecting changes in blood flow associated with neural activation, which often involves studying different types of brainwaves.']

['Larvae - A young, wingless insect in its immature form before undergoing metamorphosis into an adult.', 'Pupa - The life stage between larva and adult during which most insects transform.', 'Insect: Maggot - An early instar of a fly or other insect that feeds on decaying organic matter.', 'Dipteran - A classification for flies, including maggots.', 'Calliphoridae - The family to which houseflies and their maggots belong.', 'Oviposition - The act of a female insect laying her eggs on suitable substrates like rotting matter.', 'Colonization - The process by which maggots settle and grow in an environment with organic material as food.', 'Detritivore - An organism, such as a maggot, that feeds on decaying organic matter.', 'Vermiculture - Cultivation of worms to decompose organic waste into nutrient-rich compost', 'Myiasis - The infestation or invasion of a living tissue by fly larvae, particularly maggots.', 'Necromenous succession - A type of ecological succession that occurs when dead organisms are the primary source for new organism growth like maggots.', 'Decaying matter: The material on which maggots feed and grow, commonly referred to as carrion or putrescence.', 'Necrophagous - Feeding habits of organisms that consume dead organic matter; a category in which many insects including maggots fall under.', 'Biodegradation - The natural process by which organic substances are broken down into smaller molecules by living organisms like maggots and bacteria.', 'Saprophytic - Referring to the mode of nutrition in organisms that derive their sustenance from decaying organic matter, including maggots.', 'Decomposition: The process of breaking down complex materials like dead animals or plants into simpler compounds, which is facilitated by decomposer organisms such as maggots.', 'Coprophagy - The consumption of feces, commonly observed in some species that also includes feeding on decaying matter and can be indirectly related to the lifecycle of certain insects.', 'Excavator larvae - A term often used to describe maggots with their mouthparts adapted for burrowing into decomposing tissue or material, like those in housefly species (Calliphoridae family).', 'Fungivorous - The feeding habits of organisms that consume fungi; though not directly related to the primary diet of maggots, some may also be considered as such when consuming fungal growth on decaying matter.', "Decomposers: A broad category of organisms (including insects like maggots) responsible for breaking down dead plants and animals into simpler substances that can re-enter the ecosystem's nutrient cycle."]

['Gulyás - A traditional Hungarian beef and vegetable stew, typically served with rice or bread.', 'Pörkölt - Another popular Hungarian stew made with meat (usually pork), potatoes, onions, paprika, and other ingredients.', 'Töltél - A spicy Hungarian stew made from beef, root vegetables, and red pepper paste.', 'Csirkepaprikás - A classic Hungarian stew featuring tender chicken pieces cooked in a rich paprika sauce with onions and tomatoes.', 'Székelygulyás - A regional Hungarian stew from the Székely region, made with cabbage, potatoes, bell peppers, and smoked sausage.', 'Bortalitas - A simple yet flavorful Hungarian stew made with meatballs (bortanyi), vegetables, and spices.', 'Kisgulyás - A small-portion version of gulyás, featuring a more delicate balance of ingredients.', 'Cserkészleves - A traditional Hungarian stew from the Csikós region, made with veal, mushrooms, and spices like marjoram and parsley.', 'Vadaszterce - A rich and hearty Hungarian stew featuring large chunks of beef cooked in a tomato-based sauce with paprika and caraway seeds.', 'Csángóleves - A unique Hungarian stew named after the Csángós, an ethnic group from Transylvania; known for their ability to negotiate agreements and policies within a political system.', "Diplomat: An individual who acts as an official representative of one nation in another country's government, often involved in negotiations or discussions on foreign policy issues", 'Philanthropist: A person who seeks to promote human welfinascent through charitable donations or involvement in social causes', 'Polymath: An individual with expertise in multiple fields, often encompassing arts, sciences, and/or philosophy', "Autobiographical Skill: The ability to write an autobiography in a captivating manner; this skill is exemplified by the vivid accounts of Franklin's life presented in his autobiography.", 'Rustic simplicity: A lifestyle or design approach that emphasizes natural, unrefined materials and basic living arrangements', "Moral rectitude: The quality of being morally upright; Franklin's autobiography highlights his adherence to personal virtues such as humility, honesty, hard work, and dedication.", "Intellectual curiosity: An eagerness to learn or gain knowledge about various subjects; this trait is evident in Franklin's diverse array of accomplishments throughout his life.", "Self-education: The process by which an individual learns independently without the assistance of formal schooling, as demonstrated by Franklin's varied expertise acquired through personal reading and experimentation.", 'Wise counsel: Good advice given to someone with sound judgment; Franklin provided wise guidance on multiple occasions during his public service, including serving in roles such as a governor, diplomat, and member of the Constitutional Convention.', "Social grace: The ability to behave appropriately and politely in social situations; Franklin's autobiography shows him interacting with various individuals from different backgrounds while maintaining graciousness.", 'Virtue ethics: A philosophical perspective emphasizing the role of character traits, or virtues, in guiding moral actions; Franklin often discussed personal growth and self-improvement, rooted in his values and ideals.', 'Autocratic leadership style: The tendency to exercise absolute authority over a group while making decisions without consultation from others', 'Political satire: Humorous or exaggerated depictions of political events, figures, or institutions; Benjamin Franklin created various humorous publications such as "Poor Richard\'s Almanack" to address issues in society through witty language.', 'Moral lessons: Teachings related to ethics and moral conduct that often emerge from personal experiences or stories shared by individuals, like the anecdotes Franklin included throughout his autobiography to impart wisdom on self-improvement and virtuous living.']

['Anachronism - A chronological inconsistency in a historical narrative or artwork', 'Afterimage - A visual impression from an earlier image seen by the eye when looking away at a different subject', 'Post-Impressionism - A movement that developed after Impressionism, characterized by vivid colors and distinct brush strokes', 'Retrofitting - Adding or adapting new features to existing artwork or sculptures in an attempt to make them relevant again ', 'Revivalism - The act of bringing back old styles or elements in painting, sculpture, etc., as a current trend', 'Neo-expressionism - An art movement that emerged after the initial wave of modern art movements, characterized by intense subjectivity and rough handling of materials', 'Postmodernism - A period that followed modernism, embracing diverse styles and cultural references in painting and sculpture ', 'Neo-Classicism - An art movement inspired by classical antiquity, which arose after the initial wave of romanticism and neoclassicism itself', 'Contemporary Art - Refers to art produced from the mid-20th century to current times, reflecting current themes and practices in painting and sculpture ', 'Postmodern Sculpture - A style that emerged after modernism and contemporary art, featuring unconventional materials and forms', 'Neo-Romanticism - An artistic movement emphasizing emotional expression through painting and sculpture, following the initial wave of romanticism ', 'Hyperrealism - A style of painting or sculpture that strives to create an extremely realistic depiction of its subject matter', 'Digital Art - Any visual art created digitally using computer software, emerging as a new medium in contemporary art', 'Arte Povera - An Italian movement emphasizing the use of everyday materials and natural elements in painting and sculpture after World War II ', 'Neo-Geometric - A style characterized by geometric forms and often industrial or minimalist themes, following initial modern and contemporary movements', 'Kinetic Sculpture - Any three-dimensional artwork that incorporates motion, either through mechanical means or natural forces ', 'Pop Art - An art movement emerging after the rise of consumer culture in the mid-20th century, featuring popular cultural imagery and mass media references in painting and sculpture', 'Neo-Gothic - A style characterized by a revival of Gothic architectural elements and motifs in painting and sculpture following modernism ', 'Op Art - Short for "Optical Art," a movement that emerged after the initial wave of abstract art, using optical illusions and visual effects in paintings and sculptures', 'Conceptual Art - An art movement emphasizing ideas over traditional aesthetic or material concerns, following modern and contemporary movements ', 'Minimalism - A style characterized by extreme simplicity and reduction of form, emerging after the initial wave of abstract expressionism in painting and sculpture ', 'Land Art - An art movement that involves creating large-scale works using natural landscapes, following modernist tendencies ', 'Neo-Baroque - A style characterized by an exaggerated sense of grandeur, drama, and ornamentation in painting and sculpture after initial movements like neoclassicism ', 'Deconstructivism - An architectural movement that emerged after modernism, focusing on fragmented forms and non-linear structures', 'Abstract Illusionism - A style of painting characterized by optical illusions and complex compositions in which the subject matter is not immediately recognizable ', 'New Media Art - Any artwork created using digital or electronic technologies, emerging as a new medium after modern and contemporary movements.']

['Adenophyllum - Another name for Avaous (a genus within the family rose family)', 'Avens - Also known as common avens or heath-bedstraw, a flowering plant in the rose family', 'Dwarf mistletoe - A parasitic plant that can grow on avens and other trees and shrubs', 'Hawkweed - A genus of plants with yellow flowers that includes some species commonly found near avens ', 'Ground ivy (Creeping Charlie) - An invasive vine or creeping herbaceous plant that can be found in areas where avens grow', 'May apple (genus Sargentodoxa) - A woodland perennial flowering plant whose fruit is edible and resembles an avens flower when young', "Bird's-foot violet (Erythronium americanum) - A wildflower native to North America that produces attractive yellow flowers in the shape of avens petals ", 'Wild strawberry (Fragaria vesca) - An edible wild fruit plant with small, white flowers and red berries that can be found near avens', 'Common columbine (Aquilegia vulgaris) - A perennial flowering plant commonly known as the "cottage pink" or "hardy columbine", which has five-parted flower clusters resembling an upside-down bird\'s foot, similar to avens flowers', 'Purple coneflower (Echinacea purpurea) - A popular medicinal plant with cone-shaped flower heads in shades of pink and purple that can be found near avens ', 'Wild ginger (Asarum canadense) - An understory forest herb native to North America, which has large heart-shaped leaves and small white flowers that resemble avens blooms', 'Wood anemone (Anemone nemorosa) - A plant with delicate bell-shaped yellow or whitish flowers commonly found in wooded areas near avens ', "Solomon's seal (Polygonatum odoratum) - An herbaceous perennial native to Asia and North America, which has long rhizomes that grow along the ground like avens runners or stolons", 'Foxglove (Digitalis purpurea) - A tall biennial plant with tubular pink or white flowers commonly found in meadows and woodland edges near avens']
